The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of intense debate. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a categorical foundation for quantum theory, but they use different mathematical structures. This paper provides a common mathematical language for these programs.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have important implications for understanding the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolution of parasitic lifestyles. They also have implications for understanding the evolution of the genome and the evolution of parasitism.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the main factors that contribute to the severity of the disease caused by the infection. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1 channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These results suggest that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the production of staple crops, including maize, which is the most important cereal crop in the world. We quantify how the variability of maize yields will change in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet composition. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet composition in understanding the coexistence of LMH. It also highlights the potential of DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition at the species level. This approach will be critical for understanding the role of LMH in the functioning of ecosystems.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off or closed, and that the length of the crisis is negatively associated with the likelihood of closure. However, many businesses are financially fragile, and many anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans. Finally, we find that businesses that received loans were more likely to be open and to have more employees than businesses that did not receive loans.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of the human impact on the environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. View Full-Text

The ages of interstellar grains are important for understanding the origin of the Solar System. We determined ages of 40 large silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for understanding the formation of the Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of parental care. Here, we show that the evolution of domestication and allonursing are associated with increased reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the amount of energy available to the mother rather than an increase in the number of litters. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is a fundamental insight into the evolution of parental care and the evolution of domestication. It also has implications for the evolution of human reproduction.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the inflammatory protease caspase-1, which is activated in the brain in response to inflammation, is also able to cleave α-syn at its C terminus, thereby promoting its aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that caspase-1 inhibition may be a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of MSA. This approach could be used to treat other synucleinopathies, such as Parkinson’s disease, in which α-syn aggregation is also a major pathological feature. Finally, our results suggest that caspase-1 inhibition may be a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of other diseases in which α-syn aggregation is a major pathological feature.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for controlling the flow of blood, the clotting of blood, and the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between the blood and tissues. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling inflammation and for the regulation of blood pressure. The endothelium is a complex system of cells that must be able to communicate with each other and with other cells in order to control these functions. Here, we show that the endothelium is a highly connected network of cells that is designed to be both efficient at local and global communication. This design allows for rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. Understanding the design of the endothelium is important for understanding the control of cardiovascular function and for developing strategies to control cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data is likely to persist. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We believe that the COVIDcast API will be useful to policy makers, epidemiological modelers, and researchers in many fields. We hope that it will be a useful resource for the research community and the public health community. We also hope that it will serve as a model for the future provision of open data on public health surveillance.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be regulated by the presence of a diverse array of natural products. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identify a large number of genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for natural products, and we show that these fungi produce a variety of natural products in culture. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products, which could be harnessed as a source of antimicrobials, therapeutics, and other bioactive compounds. This study provides a foundation for future studies to investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The design of multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple material phases that seamlessly collaborate to produce desired responses. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design multifunctional architectures with highly complex yet navigable responses. The developed methodology can be utilized to design multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses for a wide range of applications. This article is protected by copyright. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of the blood. The hemoglobin content of the blood is determined by the expression of the alpha, beta, and gamma globin genes. The alpha and beta globin genes are expressed in a developmental sequence, with the alpha globin gene being expressed first, followed by the beta globin gene, and finally the gamma globin gene. This developmental sequence is important for the proper development of the blood and the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood. Here we show that the expression of the beta globin gene is reduced in human erythroid cells when the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is overexpressed. This results in a reduction of the beta globin protein and a concomitant increase of the gamma globin protein. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a potential target for the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a major cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. This mechanism involves the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which protects cancer cells from ferroptosis. We also identified a mechanism of sensitivity to ferroptosis induction, which involves the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and its transcriptional target stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), and showed that this mechanism is relevant to cancer. These findings suggest that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that transformed forest management in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet succeeded in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. Our results also show that the early-seral ecosystem, which is the focus of the recently proposed “early seral” policy, is not a panacea for the conservation of older forests. Rather, the early-seral ecosystem is a valuable tool for the conservation of early-seral bird species, but it is not a substitute for older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. We show that the design strategy is successful in identifying a compound that is active against resistant pathogens in vitro and in vivo. The identified compound is more accessible, exhibits higher binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active than the current standard of care. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of antibiotics and may help to accelerate the development of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that consists of a single set of operations. The proposed architecture is able to capture features at different image scales, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The evolution of the African continent has been shaped by the transport of moisture in the tropics. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin secretion, reduces evening sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, compared with reading a printed book. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is thought to be triggered by a bolide impact. However, the origin of the Os in the bolide is unknown. We show that the Os in the bolide is likely terrestrial, and that the impact occurred in northeastern North America, near the location of the YDB.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases is complex and depends on the stage of the disease, the type of autoantigen, and the stage of the disease.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of beetles and their diversification remain poorly understood. We used the most comprehensive dataset of beetle genomes to date to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origin of Coleoptera, the diversification of beetles and angiosperms, and the evolution of their digestive systems. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and the evolution of a suite of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of cultural traits. This is important because it suggests that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of human culture.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a protein that is produced by neurons and astrocytes, a major cell type of the central nervous system. Here, we show that APOE is important for the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is a normal process of synaptic turnover. We also show that APOE is important for the accumulation of senescent synapses in the hippocampus, which may be a cause of AD pathology. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk because of defective astrocytic phagocytosis, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. This hypothesis may explain the increased AD risk associated with APOE4. Further studies are needed to test this hypothesis. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,300 km, which is the deepest part of the planet. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of the liquid iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. They also have implications for the origin of other dense solids and for the origin of the inner core of other planets. Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation may be a key factor in the development of marijuana addiction.

Language is the defining feature of humanity, and the brain is the defining feature of language. Yet, despite decades of research, we still do not understand how the brain processes language. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks, which have revolutionized many areas of science by learning from data, also predict the brain responses to language in humans. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain mechanisms of language comprehension. They also suggest that we may be able to use artificial neural networks to understand the brain. This could lead to new ways of studying and treating language disorders.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been unstable, even though it is known to be universal. We show that this instability is a consequence of the fact that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there are no algorithms that can train such networks. This result leads to a classification theory of the conditions under which stable networks can be computed by algorithms. We also introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and fast. This work is a major step toward the development of stable and efficient algorithms for deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a story of science, politics, and the media. In this commentary, we argue that the scientific community’s focus on the alleged “misunderstanding” of exponential growth is misguided. We show that the experiment that is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon is flawed in its design and analysis. We conclude that the study should be seen as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research. We hope that this commentary will help to foster a more critical approach to the interpretation of psychological research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the disabling disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a rare reactional disease known as Lucio’s phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease, and that they have not lost the ability to cause disease.

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy is a key open problem in quantum many-body physics. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a consequence of integrability and is valid for both unitary and dissipative dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we find excellent agreement with numerical data. Our work provides a powerful framework for the study of the dynamics of entanglement and entropy in generic quantum many-body systems.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against COVID-19 is critical to combatting the pandemic. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, COVI-VAC, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is highly attenuated, has a large-scale manufacturing potential, and is protective in a relevant animal model. These properties support its potential use in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been spread by rats. Here, we use a compartmental model to show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas and lice, were the primary vectors of plague during this period. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Black Death, ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human behavior in the spread of infectious diseases.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density, which is the brain’s computational power, has been largely ignored. This study fills this gap by using the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. The evolution of brain neuronal density is characterized by four major shifts. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endotherm lineages. This study has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. We hope that our results will help to improve the understanding of the evolution of brain size and function.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. Here, we show that TRAP1 is a critical regulator of metabolism and cell function, and that its expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and their disassembly is essential for many cellular processes. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) family of proteins is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. However, how it does so is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin, a key member of the ADF family, is able to enhance the rate of actin filament severing by increasing the torque experienced by the filaments. This mechanism is critical for the function of ADF/cofilin in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of actin filaments in cells and for the design of new therapeutic strategies.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. However, the brain mechanisms underlying the effects of fructose versus glucose on appetite and food-seeking behavior are unknown. Here, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a recent demographic growth and a heterogeneous distribution of African and Asian ancestry. These results suggest that Madagascar was settled by multiple independent groups, rather than by a single population. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the human history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework for the study of the human history of other islands. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is the first experimental evidence of emotional contagion in a real-world social network. Our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact in person. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, as well as for our understanding of the role of emotions in social networks. They also have implications for the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions in social networks.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are translated into proteins, and the sequence of the mRNA can be modified after transcription. In this study, we show that the modification of a single uridine nucleotide in an mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of this modification can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of mRNA modifications can alter the rate of protein synthesis and the repertoire of peptides synthesized. This study provides insight into how mRNA modifications can impact protein synthesis and the potential consequences of the ribosome encountering mRNA modifications. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better physical and mental health, less pain, healthier lifestyles, and healthier body and brain. These associations are robust to the inclusion of factors such as prosperity, depressive symptoms, and outcomes before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that rhinovirus replication was attenuated at 33 °C, and that this was due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings suggest that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, at least in part, a consequence of the host innate immune response. Our results also suggest that the cool temperature of the nasal cavity may be an adaptive feature of the common cold virus. This may have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major human pathogen that causes a variety of diseases, including pneumonia, sepsis, and chronic lung infections. The bacterium is able to cause disease in part because it is able to adapt to its environment. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This sensing mechanism is important for the bacterium to be able to attach to the surface and for the regulation of its virulence. Our findings thus provide insights into the sensing mechanisms used by bacteria to adapt to their environment and to regulate their virulence. This knowledge may be useful for the development of new strategies to combat bacterial infections.

The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface waters and the risk of pesticide exposure to aquatic organisms. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the emergence of new variants has complicated the response. The role of animals in the spread of SARS-CoV-2 is unknown, but may be significant. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, and the observation of a dramatic increase in the prevalence of the virus in deer during the winter, when human cases are low. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. The problems are similar to those in the developed world, but the scale is much larger. The problems include the disruption of river ecology, deforestation, loss of biodiversity, greenhouse gas emissions, displacement of people, and changes to the food system, water quality, and agriculture. This paper examines the problems and proposes solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type responsible for Aβ production, are also the major source of the inflammatory response in AD. Our results suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be the primary cause of the neuroinflammation, which is a key feature of AD.

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is also one of the most enigmatic. The earliest evidence for the use of chickens for economic purposes is still missing. We present a detailed analysis of the chicken remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for eggs and meat was widespread at that site. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken. (PsycINFO Database Record

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the folding pathway is not known for most proteins. Here we report the results of a detailed study of the folding of a large protein, the maltose binding protein. We show that the folding pathway is not random but is highly constrained by the structure of the protein. The folding pathway is also not unique but is highly sensitive to the presence of mutations that alter the structure of the protein. These results are important for understanding the folding of other proteins. They also suggest that the folding of proteins is not a random process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing these caps, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress, prefers to remove capped RNAs as substrates over their capped counterparts. This enzyme, which recognizes capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, generates monophosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping, requiring a second deprotection step to produce the 5′ terminus needed to stimulate rapid RNA degradation. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation while reducing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. Our results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of all living organisms is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a quantitative view of the biomass of all kingdoms of life is still lacking. Here, we assemble a census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, establishing a global picture of the biomass composition of the biosphere. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all plants. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all plants. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere. This is key for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, which is characterized by the fact that the system is always in a critical state, and that the rate of change of the system is proportional to the current system activity. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, such as sandpiles, neural networks, and fracture processes. In this paper, we study a continuous model of SOC, which is a scaling limit of the sandpile model. We show that the model exhibits a critical state, and that the rate of change of the system activity is proportional to the current system activity. We also show that the model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and thermal management. However, diamond is unstable under large mechanical strain, which limits its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and the bandgap can be tuned continuously. This work provides a new way to tailor the properties of diamond, which is of great significance for the development of diamond-based devices. Our findings also provide insights into the stability of diamond under large mechanical strain. This work will help to promote the development of diamond-based devices and applications. This study provides insights into the structural architecture, antifungal activity, and mode of action of a unique NCR peptide. It also demonstrates the potential of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The female reproductive tract is the site of fertilization, and it is therefore critical to understand the interactions between sperm and the female reproductive tract. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome after mating, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community because it provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. It will also be of interest to the general public because it provides a unique perspective on the role of the female reproductive tract in reproduction.

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) binds to platelets, where it is essential for stopping bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application switches the A1 domain of VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the function of VWF in the blood.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses from human samples, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. We find that viruses are associated with many diseases, and that these associations are not explained by known bacteria–disease associations. These results highlight the importance of viruses in human health and the need for further study.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system, but it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. Continuous observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of the early Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin of life. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth has been inferred from the isotopic compositions of marine cherts. However, the isotopic record may have been reset by diagenesis or metamorphism. We show that ancestral enzymes, which are the biochemical building blocks of proteins, are extremely thermostable, a property that is compatible with a hot early Earth. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth decreased over geological time.

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell and are regulated by two types of gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel, which is normally open, possesses two pore gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The BK channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and can be closed by channel opening. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide insights into the regulation of ion channels and the mechanism of C-type inactivation. They also suggest that the BK channel may be a promising target for drug development. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to bind to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface, which alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane and cytoskeleton. This change in the RBC allows the parasite to invade the RBC more easily. This work suggests that the malaria parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work has important implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (PsycINFO Database Record

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, photonics, and optics. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. Therefore, it is desirable to control its mechanical properties, such as strength and ductility, to improve its applications. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, or demetallized, reversibly through strain engineering. This work provides a new way to control the mechanical properties of diamond, which can be used to improve its applications. Our findings also provide a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond and its mechanical properties. This work is expected to inspire the development of new materials and applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease, and seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may inform the development of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of influenza-associated respiratory disease. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s response to language varies with each successive word, but suddenly when words can be merged into phrases. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to build phrases from words, and that this operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More generally, our results suggest that the brain may use a similar operation to build hierarchical representations of all types of information. This operation may be a fundamental component of the brain’s information processing system.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is important for development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the Wnt signal, which is important for the proper development of the organism.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated mice, and that this effect is blocked by lesions of the ventral tegmental area, substantia nigra, or peri-locus coeruleus. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it is not involved in normal feeding. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may also have implications for the treatment of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of this essential element is the main limiting factor for crop yields. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, so that they only fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant, could be a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a system that allows us to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, so that they only fix nitrogen when in contact with the desired host plant.

We study the effectiveness of a community-based monitoring program that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. We show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the ALK/LTK family of receptors in vivo. This finding is important for understanding the role of ALK/LTK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. In addition, we show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the ALK/LTK family of receptors in vitro. This finding is important for understanding the role of ALK/LTK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Finally, we show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to cause loss of iridophores in vivo. This finding is important for understanding the role of ALK/LTK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Together, our results provide evidence for a role of ALK/LTK in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is important for understanding the role of ALK/LTK in the development of cancer.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has caused devastating outbreaks throughout human history, is a complex process that has been poorly understood. Here, we present the genomes of 17 ancient plague strains, dating to the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age, and explore their diversity and evolution. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique perspective on the origins of plague and its impact on human history. It also has implications for understanding the spread of disease in the past and present.

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can most effectively sequester SOC on grasslands are not well understood. We show that soil health management practices that are commonly used in annual cropping systems can increase SOC storage in grasslands. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and manure addition. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester SOC and provide a strategy for climate-smart agriculture. This study also highlights the importance of soil microbial traits in the response of SOC to agricultural management. Our results suggest that the management practices that increase SOC storage in grasslands may also increase the stability of SOC in the soil. This study provides a framework for understanding the role of grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. (Show more)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. Using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world, we ranked the spillover potential of 887 wildlife viruses. Validating the risk assessment, the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to animal pollinators. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this compound and show that these enzymes are necessary for the production of the red color. Our findings suggest that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie the evolution of the red color in nectar. This work provides a molecular basis for the evolution of a visually important trait in plants. It also highlights the importance of studying the chemical basis for the evolution of plant traits.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The ability to rapidly identify the pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of pathogen RNA from febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and leptospirosis. This study demonstrates that mNGS can be used to identify the pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to better understand the pathogen landscape in other resource-scarce settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The structure of the human pol δ holoenzyme is known, but the stability of the complex is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study also provides a unique system to study the stability of a protein–protein complex in vitro. We believe that this system will be useful for studying other protein–protein complexes in the future.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In this study, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA. This polymerase can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can amplify RNA by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life and the evolution of RNA-based life.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in areas that are already attractive. These results are important for understanding the physical dynamics of cities and for developing effective policies to improve the physical appearances of neighborhoods.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, could significantly improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and reduce mortality. Therefore, tocilizumab is a promising treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to control copper homeostasis is critical for their survival in the environment and in the human body. Here we describe the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work demonstrates the existence of a previously unknown role for eukaryotic natural products in the control of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the role of fungi in the human body and the environment. It also has implications for the development of antifungal and antibacterial agents. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature SiO2 polymorph, in a sedimentary mudstone at the surface of Mars is a surprising discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, and the mudstone is a sedimentary deposit. The tridymite is a product of high-temperature diagenesis of a high-SiO2 glass and/or precipitated silica, and the mixed-cation salts and oxides are products of multiple aqueous infiltrations. The diagenesis of the mudstone is consistent with the presence of a “Lake Gale” catchment environment at the time of deposition. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to the ongoing climate change. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether these cells are required for the development of disease or are simply part of the inflammatory response. Here, we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis and that this requirement is dependent on the development of Th1-like cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important mediators of the inflammatory response in inflammatory bowel disease, but they are not the only cells required for the development of disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and identify therapeutic targets. This method will also enable the production of large numbers of cells for drug screening to identify compounds that can alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will be a powerful tool for ALS research and drug discovery.

The role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to vectors is a rapidly emerging area of research. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We identify a protein that is expressed by the vector and that alters the composition of the gut microbiota. This protein, which binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall, alters the permeability of the gut and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from an arthropod vector to alter the microbiota and more efficiently colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence vector behavior and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. Birds are one of the most successful animal lineages, and the study of their evolution is critical for understanding the origin of modern avian traits. However, the study of the origin of birds has been hindered by a lack of knowledge about the diversity of early members of the group. Here, we describe a new basal bird, which provides important information about the origin of birds.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with the temperature of the troposphere, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. However, some vertebrates have distinctive blue-green tissues, which are caused by unusually high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. We show that the presence of high biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins, are most similar to human anti-trypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and introduces a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of color and the biochemical basis of chlorosis. They also have implications for understanding the function of serpins in vertebrates

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. The development of breast cancer is associated with the hypoxic tumor microenvironment, which is characterized by low oxygen levels. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, which demethylates NANOG mRNA, leading to increased NANOG protein levels and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is induced by the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α, and is required for the BCSC phenotype. Thus, HIF-dependent ALKBH5 expression mediates enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer.
