The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for the identification of the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the origin of parchment in the future.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical to understanding the cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is constrained to within 60 ± 48 ka, and the onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle occurs immediately before the onset of extinction. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. This work establishes a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The results will also be critical to evaluating the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also show that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our findings suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated epigenetic regulation of NF-κB signaling is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. This study provides insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of IBD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We use cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor ACE2 and the cellular protease TMPRSS2. We find that the D614G mutation, which is present in the currently circulating variants, leads to a more open conformation of the spike. This may facilitate binding to the cellular receptor and the subsequent conformational changes required for membrane fusion. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase the transmissibility of the virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the well-known result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) for finite games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the properties of compounds. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and we propose a new way to understand the chemical properties of atoms. Our results are relevant to the understanding of the properties of compounds under pressure, and they are also of general interest in the field of quantum chemistry.

Fire is a key natural process in terrestrial ecosystems, but its role in the climate system is complex, with feedbacks that can amplify or attenuate warming. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of fire activity in the 20th century, and that these changes are likely to continue in the future. This has important implications for the climate system, as changes in fire activity can reduce warming. However, the risk is that more extreme fires will occur in the future, which could reverse this effect. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the role of human activities in shaping the future of fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread phenomenon in nature. However, the mechanisms by which these interactions are established and maintained are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the dynamics of a symbiont in a specific host–microbe interaction. This glycan is released by host immune cells in a specific manner, at a specific time of day, and is catabolized by the symbiont only at night. These findings suggest that the provision of nutrients may be a common mechanism for regulating the activities of epithelial-associated microbial communities. This study also provides a mechanism for understanding the evolution of circadian rhythms in host–microbe interactions. (PsycINFO Database Record

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in the data. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding. We first identify a set of vectors that can be interpreted as latent topics. We then infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. We believe that our method will be useful to many domains, including psychology, sociology, medicine, and law. We hope that our method will inspire others to develop applications that use text data to understand the world.

The second plague pandemic, which began in the 14th century, was the consequence of the introduction of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, into Europe. This study shows that the introduction of plague into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather repeated, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y between each introduction. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the introduction of plague into Europe was the consequence of the movement of people and goods along the ancient Silk Road. This study also highlights the importance of climate variability in the spread of plague. The timing of the introduction of plague into Europe was strongly linked to the climate conditions in Asia, which suggests that climate change may have played a role in the spread of plague in the 21st century.

Asteroid species are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for a variety of predators. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that leads to behavioral changes, lesions, loss of turgor, limb autotomy, and death. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation (“melting”). We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the starfish itself. The virus is present in plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that it can be spread by the movement of animals. The findings provide evidence that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the starfish itself. The findings also provide evidence that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted by the starfish itself.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with a poor prognosis, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor are effective in AML xenograft models. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects, and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, our results suggest that IL-1 signaling may be a potential therapeutic target in AML. Thus, our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AML. Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a recent demographic growth and a heterogeneous distribution of African and Asian ancestry. These results suggest that Madagascar was settled by multiple independent groups, rather than by a single population. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for understanding the human history of Madagascar and for the conservation of its biodiversity. View Full-Text

Bacteria are able to regulate the expression of genes in response to environmental changes. In some cases, the regulation of gene expression is mediated by small RNAs. These RNAs are thought to be noncoding, but a few have been found to encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. We also show that the RNA base pairs with the cadA and galE promoters, and that this base pairing interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete for the same resource. This is an example of a mechanism that may be used by bacteria to regulate the expression of genes in response to environmental changes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their assessments are subjective and categorical. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies, which is critical for the management of agricultural production. The proposed methodology can be easily extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features within the brain. It also suggests a mechanism for the formation of memory traces that can be accessed without explicit retrieval. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. We highlight the importance of future studies that focus on the response of soil respiration to warming in a variety of biomes. This is critical to improving our understanding of the role of soil respiration in the global carbon cycle and the potential for further increases in global temperatures.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a common feature of many modern plant species, is associated with a gradual relaxation of purifying selection on the plastid genome. We propose a model of the evolutionary trajectory of the plastid genome under progressively relaxed functional constraints during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the plastid genome and for the origin of life. View Full-Text

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water security. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for water resource managers, policy makers, and the general public in SSA and beyond. It also highlights the need for urgent mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of future droughts.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known example of a quasicrystal, found in a meteorite, is now over 40 years old. Here, we report the discovery of a second example of a quasicrystal, this time in a sample of the “Trinity” test of a nuclear bomb. The age of the sample is known precisely because it contains a glass of the material that formed the test site. This discovery has implications for the search for new quasicrystal-forming materials and for the study of the history of the universe. It also has implications for the safety of nuclear weapons.

Photosynthesis is the process by which solar energy is converted into chemical energy, which is stored in the form of carbohydrates. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is mediated by the pigments, chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides insights into the role of ASK1 in the pathogenesis of EAE and suggests a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of neuro

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is not well understood. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results suggest that behavioral inflexibility is a common consequence of autism-risk genes and that forgetting is a common mechanism. These findings may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of forgetting in behavior. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 can lead to severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1, which result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of bleeding diathesis and congenital myopathy. Our findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of CRAC channel dysregulation, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The study of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is of great interest to the scientific community and the public at large. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to show that protein aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insight into the mechanisms underlying spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and the potential of bats as a source of emerging viruses. These findings are of great importance for the development of a better understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and the potential of bats as a source of emerging viruses. Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell cancer cells. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for the treatment of cancer. This work has implications for the treatment of other cancers, and for the development of metabolic inhibitors in general.

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients is a common feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the presence of proteins that are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other tissues, is a unique feature of ALS. This suggests that the presence of proteins that are supersaturated in motor neurons is a consequence of the disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This, in turn, may be a consequence of the unique features of the motor neurons in ALS, such as the presence of inclusions of mutant superaggregation-prone proteins. Thus, the presence of proteins that are supersaturated in motor neurons may be a consequence of the disease process in ALS. This may have important implications for the design of therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that this work will inspire future experiments and applications in many-body physics and quantum technologies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has helped to clarify some of the issues. Montsechia is an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and is sister to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is an important plant for understanding the evolution of the flowering plants because it is an early member of the Ceratophyllum clade.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the scientific community, but the study of virus evolution has been hindered by the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This study also provides a glimpse into the past, and the ancient viral sequences presented here can be used to study the evolution of viruses in the future. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This is a well-known phenomenon, but the rate of rise is not well known. We provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise, which is 25 y running average of the rate of change of the mean sea level over the period 1993–2017. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that the rate of acceleration is also increasing.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase has been greater for those born after 1950. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain. Tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This approach offers a powerful tool for understanding the mechanisms of enzyme reactions, and we anticipate that it will be widely applied in the future.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a zoonotically transmitted coronavirus. The high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of remdesivir in MERS patients. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of prophylaxis in the case of zoonotic coronaviruses. Prophylactic remdesivir treatment prevented MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates, and may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The provision of nutrients to microbial communities associated with epithelial surfaces is a widespread phenomenon in nature. However, the mechanisms by which these interactions are established and maintained are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the establishment and maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. This glycan is provided by the host only at night, when the symbiont is most active, and its catabolism is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic crypts. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general mechanism for the establishment and maintenance of epithelial microbial communities. This study also highlights the importance of the timing of nutrient provision in these interactions. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the study of the surfaceome in cancer cells, and find that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by oncogenes, and that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with a recently developed technique that allows for the analysis of intact glycopeptides, and find that oncogenes dramatically alter the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a framework for understanding the cell surface proteome in cancer cells, and may lead to the development of new strategies for cancer therapy. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a widespread call for the expansion of vote-by-mail programs to safeguard the 2020 election. However, the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes have not been systematically studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is unlikely to affect the 2020 election.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to the development of a large body of work on the structure, function, and evolution of SARS-CoV-2. However, the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique mechanism for immune suppression. The structure provides insight into the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease. This work provides a foundation for future studies on the role of ORF8 in the disease process and for the development of therapeutics. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. The analysis of data is a major activity in science and engineering. The analysis of big data is a major activity in the era of big data. The analysis of data is also a major activity in the study of science and engineering. The analysis of big data is also a major activity in the study of big data. In this paper, we describe some recent developments in the analysis of data that are designed to help us to assess the strength of associations that we find. These developments are needed because we have “cherry-picked”—searched for the strongest associations—and so must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs has been difficult, and the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the generation of ECs from primary human skin fibroblasts. Our study provides a strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. These findings may lead to the development of a therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders and the regeneration of organs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We report the discovery of a third class of ligands for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophore system, which is a pigment-producing system that is analogous to vertebrate eyes. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the function of RTKs in development and disease. It also provides a model system for the study of the role of RTKs in human development and disease. Finally, it provides a model for the study of the role of ligand-activated RTKs in the development of other systems.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been extensively studied, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide insights into the molecular basis of T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome into the virion. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and may have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical event in the disturbed flow-induced vascular endothelial activation. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. Therefore, the present study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerosis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the prevention of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but they can also be a threat to human communities. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that humans have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion has been driven by human activities. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should focus on reducing the number of ignitions, and on reducing the number of wildfires that occur in regions where they are most damaging.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, neighborhoods with more educated residents and better initial appearances are more likely to experience physical improvements. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in areas that are densely populated by college-educated adults and that are physically attractive. These results have implications for urban planning and for the study of urban change more generally.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides insights into the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the arthropod–plant adaptation. This study is also of interest to the medical field, as scorpion venom contains TRP channels. View Full-Text

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide insights into the metabolic processes that are likely to be involved in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, and may ultimately help us to understand the stability of other endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn activate a JNK-mediated feedback loop that triggers a dysbiotic microbiome and tumor growth. Our work identifies a mechanism that links intestinal tumors to the microbiome, and it highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors and for developing strategies to control tumor growth. They also provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between host–microbe homeostasis and inflammation. This work may also have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in the development of other diseases.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to it. We show that the expression of a type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor, ROR1, is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. This up-regulation of ROR1 is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are important in the regulation of breast cancer stemness. Furthermore, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can eradicate PDXs, and that this treatment is more effective than treatment with chemotherapy alone. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This approach may be particularly useful in the treatment of patients with metastatic breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series occurred exactly at the time of deglaciation, and that the eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which could have caused changes in the general circulation and climate. These changes, in turn, could have led to the rapid deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in global assessments of the state of the world’s fisheries. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. This analysis underscores the need for improved management of freshwater fisheries to protect both biodiversity and food security.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of the adult nervous system. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the dendrite, which is a common feature of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. Our study suggests that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between this form of regeneration and conditioning of the adult nervous system to regenerate after injury. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This work may also have implications for understanding the mechanisms underlying the regenerative capacity of the mammalian CNS in response to injury.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution is strikingly similar to that in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the process of recombination initiation, which is the focus of this study, has been conserved in eukaryotes for a very long time.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of functionally interconnected networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the organization of the brain and its functional role in health and disease. Here, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality, positron emission tomography, to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We show that the dominant resting metabolic network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We demonstrate that the dominant resting metabolic network is reduced in Parkinson’s disease, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a method for the identification of resting state networks, and for the assessment of their functional role in health and disease. This method can be used to study the effects of neurodegenerative diseases, and to monitor the effects of therapeutic interventions.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the most studied modification is the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. In this study, we show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This finding suggests that NAD-RNA is a widespread modification in eukaryotes, and that it may play a role in the regulation of gene expression.

The study shows that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes, and that these loci are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The study also provides a possible epigenetic explanation for the beneficial effects of statins on the progression of diabetes complications. These results may also have implications for the treatment of other metabolic diseases.
This study provides insights into the role of FSIP1 in the drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder, which is characterized by a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides evidence for the reversibility of the biological and behavioral parameters after a short-term detoxification program. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is determined by the composition of its volatile chemical composition. This composition is highly variable, and the underlying mechanisms are not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the volatile chemicals. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a novel method to record from a large number of neurons in the MEC while mice freely explored an open field. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for navigation, are strongly clustered, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells tend to intermingle. These results suggest that grid cells may be largely distinct from other cell types in the MEC and that grid cells may be strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. Our method should allow detailed analysis of the organization of neurons in MEC during behavior, and thus should advance our understanding of the functional role of MEC in navigation. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study demonstrates that flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine system of the brain and body. It is caused by degeneration of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, a structure in the midbrain. We show that the dopamine-producing neurons are also influenced by other neurons in the midbrain. These other neurons are located in the striatum, a structure in the forebrain. We suggest that the striatum is involved in the regulation of dopamine-related behavior.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by others to judge the quality of the connection between two people, and it is used by the people themselves to judge the quality of their connection. This signal is fast, honest, and automatic, and it is therefore likely to be a robust and fundamental way that people feel connected to each other.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are characterized by the presence of internal Ca2+ stores and a unique electrical architecture. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in SAN cells and is required for the maintenance of Ca2+ stores and the electrical activity of the SAN. These findings reveal a role for STIM1 in the regulation of Ca2+ stores and electrical activity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms that govern the function of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in the accumulation of Si and the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the defense response against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of sustainable pest management strategies. (Show more)

The lipidome is the complete set of lipids in a cell. It is a key factor in the regulation of cellular functions. The lipidome is affected by many factors, including the activity of enzymes involved in lipid metabolism. Here we show that the activity of a specific enzyme, alkylglycerol monooxygenase, is a key factor in the regulation of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. This enzyme is also involved in the metabolism of other lipids, including glycosylated ceramides and cardiolipins, which have no direct connection to ether lipid pathways. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our results suggest that memory is a dynamic process that is continuously read back into the active membrane state for processing. This mechanism is not reliant on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity for storage. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for plant cell internalization and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the context of agriculture, medicine, and other biological applications.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In this study, we show that the majority of the nutrients that fuel algal blooms in the nearshore zone of a large lake originate from small tributaries. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds, which are often overlooked in current efforts to reduce nutrient loading. Our results also highlight the importance of dissolved inorganic forms of nutrients in the nearshore zone, which are more bioavailable to algae and can be more difficult to remove through conventional wastewater treatment processes. Our work provides a framework for understanding the role of small watersheds in coastal eutrophication and suggests that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to these areas. This approach could help protect valuable nearshore ecosystems and improve the sustainability of water resources in the Anthropocene.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small fraction of the possible chemical configurations. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. We show that this behavior is a consequence of the interplay between the dynamics of the network and the environment, and that it is not a consequence of the specific form of the network. Our results suggest that the dynamics of complex systems may be biased toward states that are not necessarily the most probable ones, but rather the ones that are most adapted to the environment. This finding may have implications for the understanding of the emergence of complex behavior in complex systems.

We show that the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain are not limited to the synapse, but extend to the level of the network. This is a major advance in our understanding of the effects of these antibodies, and may have implications for the treatment of patients.

The history of carbon (C) perturbation events throughout Earth’s history has provided key insights into how the Earth system responds to abrupt warming. However, most studies focused on short-term warming events superimposed on longer-term greenhouse climate states. Here, we present an integrated proxy (C and uranium [U] isotopes and paleo CO2) and multicomponent modeling approach to investigate an abrupt C perturbation and global warming event (∼304 Ma) that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We report pronounced negative C and U isotopic excursions coincident with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 partial pressure and a biodiversity nadir. The isotopic excursions can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived C over a large area and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Earth system modeling indicates that widespread anoxic conditions can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during this global warming within an icehouse. This study provides a unique insight into the Earth system response to abrupt warming and the role of the biosphere in the evolution of the Earth system. This article is protected by copyright. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but only after the majority of forests had been cleared. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the release of proteins and other molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and other organelles. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of this process. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of exocytosis and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This study also provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of exocytosis and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of the evolution of sex differences. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species. We find that the interaction of multiple sex determination alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and behavior. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct forms of oxidative stress. The first is the photochemical oxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) by light, which leads to the accumulation of lipofuscin, a complex mixture of oxidized and reduced forms of vitamin A. The second form of oxidative stress is the photochemical oxidation of the photoreceptor cell pigment, A2E, which leads to the formation of dicarbonyls and the degradation of the pigment. We show that the levels of iron in the retina impact the oxidation and degradation of lipofuscin and A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the levels of iron in the retina may be a target for therapeutic intervention. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved modularity in their feeding strategies, and that these modularities are associated with the evolution of specialization. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help us to understand how the evolution of specialization has shaped the structure of ecosystems. This work is relevant to a wide range of disciplines, including ecology, evolution, and biology.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. However, the origin of the distinctive morphology of the hand in modern humans and Neandertals is poorly understood. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the hand that is present in modern humans and Neandertals but not in earlier hominins, is present in a Middle Pleistocene hominin from Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and for the origin of modern human behavior. It also has implications for the interpretation of the evolution of the hand in the hominin fossil record.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is a key enzyme in one-carbon metabolism. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell cancer cells. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a disease in which the cancer cells are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, one-carbon metabolism is a metabolic pathway that can be targeted therapeutically in a variety of cancer types. This work provides a framework for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A, and thus their dietary vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which is associated with higher dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of environmental change on people’s diets. This is an important contribution to the literature on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

The history of modern agriculture is the history of mechanization, with the increase in vehicle weight leading to the expansion of arable land. However, the weight of modern farm machinery has increased so much that it now exceeds the weight of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. Our findings call for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. This would help to ensure that the benefits of mechanization are not lost in the face of climate change, and that the future of agriculture is sustainable. View Full-Text
